newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso ends firm on money market demand.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso ends firm on money market demand.

text.p: The Mexican peso extended its early turnaround by the close on Monday, with longer contracts ending firmer after investors sold dollars to take advantage of high rates in the local money market, traders said.
"Foreign investors stepped in to sell dollars and bought heavily in the debt market, a dealer said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour stablemate both ended 2.5 centavos firmer at 7.8120/7.8150 and 7.8070/7.8120 per dollar, respectively.
Demand for paper in the secondary money market had driven overnight Cetes rates down by 525 basis points to 19.00 percent in late trade on Monday.
Traders noted demand for Mexican paper was strong enough for the peso to offset the adverse effect of the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond, off 12/32 in late trade to yield 6.48 percent.
Same-day peso contracts had earlier closed dealing for the day 1.6 centavos weaker at 7.8220/7.8250 per dollar.
Dealers said they did not expect the peso to strengthen beyond 7.8100 per dollar on Tuesday.
"Banks may choose to exercise dollar puts with the central bank, and that would make for a very strong resistance," a dealer said.
